questions.question: According to the 'Niche Specificity' framework in Lesson 1, why is targeting a 'general ADHD' audience often less effective than a micro-niche like 'ADHD for Female Entrepreneurs'?
options: Generalist marketing increases decision fatigue and reduces perceived expertise
Broad niches are legally required to have clinical oversight
Specific niches allow for higher advertising costs on social media
Most ADHD clients prefer to work with generalists to avoid stigma
questions.explanation: Lesson 1 emphasizes that micro-niching reduces the 'paradox of choice' for clients with executive dysfunction and establishes the practitioner as a specialist, allowing for higher premium pricing.

questions.question: A practitioner transitions from an hourly billing model to a 'Value-Based' package model. Based on Lesson 6, what is the primary financial benefit of this shift?
options: It allows the practitioner to work more hours per week
It decouples income from time, rewarding efficiency and outcome rather than duration
It eliminates the need for professional liability insurance
It ensures that clients pay exactly the same amount regardless of their progress
questions.explanation: Value-based pricing focuses on the transformation and results provided to the client, which allows the practitioner to increase revenue without necessarily increasing their working hours.

questions.question: In Lesson 3's discussion on Legal & Ethical Frameworks, what is the 'Golden Rule' regarding the scope of practice for a non-clinical ADHD Support Specialist?
options: Specialists can provide medication adjustments if they have a certification
Specialists must never use the word 'ADHD' in their marketing
Specialists support functional outcomes and do not diagnose or treat mental pathology
Specialists are legally identical to Licensed Clinical Social Workers (LCSWs)
questions.explanation: To remain ethically and legally compliant, support specialists focus on executive function strategies, lifestyle support, and functional goals rather than clinical diagnosis or medical treatment.

questions.question: When designing 'ADHD-Accessible Marketing' (Lesson 4), which design principle is most critical for reducing cognitive load for potential clients?
options: Using high-contrast, flashing neon colors to grab attention
Writing long, detailed paragraphs to explain every facet of the program
Utilizing 'chunking' with clear headers, bullet points, and ample white space
Requiring a 10-step form to ensure the client is truly committed
questions.explanation: ADHD-friendly marketing must accommodate executive function challenges. 'Chunking' information makes it easier to process and reduces the likelihood of the client becoming overwhelmed and abandoning the page.

questions.question: Lesson 5 highlights 'Operational Systems' as a tool to combat the 'ADHD Tax' in business. Which of the following is an example of an operational system reducing this 'tax'?
options: Manually emailing every client a reminder the night before a session
Using automated scheduling software with integrated 24-hour SMS reminders
Allowing clients to pay whenever they remember to do so
Keeping all client notes in various physical notebooks to avoid digital distractions
questions.explanation: Automated systems reduce the administrative burden (the 'ADHD tax' of forgotten tasks or lost time) for both the practitioner and the client, ensuring higher attendance and consistent revenue.

questions.question: According to the 'Premium Pricing Strategies' in Lesson 6, what is the effect of 'Price Anchoring' during a discovery call?
options: It makes the practitioner feel more confident about their fees
It establishes a high-value reference point, making the final investment feel more accessible
It prevents the client from asking for a discount
It is a mandatory legal requirement for all service contracts
questions.explanation: Price anchoring involves presenting a higher-tier or higher-value option first, which sets the perceived value of the service and makes subsequent options appear more reasonable by comparison.

questions.question: Lesson 7 discusses scaling through group programs. What is the 'Hybrid Model' of delivery?
options: Combining ADHD coaching with physical fitness training
A mix of pre-recorded digital content and live group coaching sessions
Working with both children and adults in the same session
Using both a laptop and a tablet to record sessions
questions.explanation: The hybrid model uses digital products (videos/worksheets) for education and live sessions for implementation and community, maximizing the practitioner's time leverage.

questions.question: In Lesson 8, the 'Referral Ecosystem' strategy suggests that the most valuable partners are 'Upstream' partners. Who is an example of an upstream partner for an ADHD Specialist?
options: A web designer who works with small businesses
A psychiatrist who diagnoses ADHD but does not provide behavioral support
A client who has already finished their 6-month program
A local printing shop that makes business cards
questions.explanation: An 'upstream' partner is someone who sees the client *before* they need your services. A psychiatrist who provides the diagnosis but not the subsequent coaching is a primary source of high-quality referrals.

questions.question: A practitioner is experiencing burnout due to 'high-touch' 1-on-1 demands. Based on Lesson 2, which business model shift is most appropriate?
options: Increasing the number of 1-on-1 clients to make more money
Lowering prices to attract more clients
Transitioning to a 'One-to-Many' model such as a membership or group program
Closing the practice for 6 months to recover
questions.explanation: The 'One-to-Many' model allows the practitioner to serve more people in less time, increasing revenue while decreasing the individual emotional and temporal load of 1-on-1 work.

questions.question: According to the statistics cited in Lesson 5, practitioners who implement automated billing and intake systems see an average increase in 'billable hour efficiency' of:
questions.explanation: Lesson 5 cites that automation of administrative tasks (intake, billing, scheduling) typically reclaims 25-40% of a practitioner's time, which can then be converted into billable client hours.
